statement.p: Explain how to find a basis in \Span\{v_1, \cdots , v_m\}.

Let v_1, \cdots , v_k be linearly independent vectors in \R^n . Describe an algorithm that finds a basis of \R^n containing v_1, \cdots , v_k. (Hint: form the matrix [v_1,\cdots,v_k,e_1,\cdots,e_n] and find pivotal columns. Why are the first k columns pivotal?)
If S is a subspace of \R^n what is the relationship between n and the dimension of S?
Determine the dimension of the subspace W of \R^3 defined by W=\{\vec{x y 0} | x \in \R \text{ and } y \in \R \}. Give its geometric description.

answer.p: We notice that even though we are in \R^3 not all three coordinates of the typical element of this subspace are independent. There is a pattern. We can write \vec{x y 0}=\vec{x 0 0}+\vec{0 y 0}=x\vec{1 0 0} + y\vec{0 1 0} Thus, we see that B=\{\vec{1 0 0}, \vec{0 1 0}\} spans W. It is also linearly independent. Hence it is a basis for W. It follows that \dim(W)=2. W is the set of vectors in \R^3 whose third coordinate is zero. These vectors only have an x and y coordinate. Therefore, they live in the x-y plane in \R^3.

statement.p: Prove that S=\{1, x, x^2\} is a basis for P_2, the set of polynomials of degree less than or equal to 2.

answer.p:
We need to prove that S spans P_2 and is linearly independent.
S spans P_2. A typical polynomial of degree less than or equal to 2 is ax^2+bx+c.
S is linearly independent. Here, we need to show that the only solution to a(1)+bx+cx^2=0 is a=b=c=0. From algebra, we remember that two polynomials are equal if and only if their corresponding coeÂ¢ cients are equal. The zero polynomial has all its coefficients equal to zero. So, a(1)+bx+cx^2=0 if and only if a=b=c=0. Hence S is linearly independent.
